narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: 1. There were texts used in other related classes I found useful and ones mentioned in this class I wished had also been assigned.5. The instructor was wonderfully available and ready to engage on any subject of interest and concern.7. I wish the instructor had provided our written work back with comments and guidance, or engaged them as much as she did us as individuals.

Susan Clark is an expert and loves teaching the policy sciences, which really helps the students learn the material. She absolutely loves answering questions and he field trips really help with understanding the policy sciences.
Timeline and expectations need to be laid out more clearly at the beginning of the semester

Question 1: Susan picks great readings, and is an exceptional writer, so we always benefit from reading her work. There are too many readings to fit into the time we have for this course, but fortunately, this semester she did not assign all of those readings. It would be nice to have required and recommended readings every week.Question 2: These concepts are difficult to grasp, and I feel like our class didn't ever get to the point where our discussions were as illuminating as they could have been. I think something that would have helped would have been to start the class with a guest lecture, followed by discussion, rather than the other way around which is usually how it happened.Question 3: The short answer assignments were not very helpful because we got no feedback on them, but they did force students to do the reading. The longer projects are always valuable, because the value of the class is being able to apply the concepts to a specific example, especially one from the student's past or current experience.Question 4: To do all the reading and really understand what is going on enough to be an active participant requires a significant amount of work.Question 6: I feel like there could have been a better structure to the class so we really knew what we were supposed to be learning each day. Susan tried to accomplish this with semi-regular updates on "where we are and where we're going," but it was still vague.Question 7: Susan has unique insights that have taught me more than any other professor at Yale. She makes more time for students than any other professor and really involves herself in enhancing our learning experience. Jenn also devotes an enormous amount of time to helping students grasp difficult concepts, although she can sometimes be difficult to reach on email.Question 9: I participated in the field trip to Arizona. It went fairly smoothly, although understandably some things deviated from the schedule as weather and other factors caused cancellations. Perhaps if we had been able to decide earlier who was going to participate and who we should coordinate with or get in touch with, we could have had more people to interview. However, it was an extremely valuable experience. It was also a lot of work, and would have been nice to receive some sort of extra credit as recognition of the fact (perhaps by getting 4 credits for the class instead of 3, for example).Question 10: This is hands down the most valuable course at FES for students with interests similar to mine.

I think the class should be divided into two class sessions because it is important to be exposed to the policy sciences material more than once a week. Having the class twice each week would allow students to engage the material more often.

This course provides new skills in thinking more effectively and acting more responsibly in complex species and ecosystem management cases. The course presents conceptual tools to integrate, synthesize, and locate the best arenas for interventions that would facilitate problem-resolution.This can be best summarized with various quotes from the course's readings:Resource problems are not really environmental problems: They are human problems that we have created at many times and in many places, under a variety of political, social, and economic systems. As such, it is important to understand that science alone will not prevent species extinctions and that we need to look at the human envelop around species recovery.What more can be said of a course taught by a scientist and an expert in endangered species that teaches us that if we truly want to be successful in species management, we need to take a hard look at the social and decision process context, in addition to the science of species recovery. This course provides the foundation of true problem solving orientation that FES needs.
The instructor, TA and other students brought this course alive and modeled both why we need an interdisciplinary policy framework and how effective it can be.
All of the guest speakers!
The field trip, the book Averting Extinction, your analysis of a recovery plan.
The readings, topics, fieldtrip, presentations - sum of everything
The trip to Arizona and the opportunity to do a project focused on a specific species recovery plan.
The readings and the additional insights provided by guest speakers.
The field trip to AZ. This was a very useful and helpful practical application of the policy sciences.

Susan's involvement with her students and dedication to the course sets a high standard for classes here at FES. Her passion for the subject was inspirational and her real-life experience more than impressive. Jenn (the TA) also was very dedicated to the students in the course, always making herself available for discussion and questions.
- Knowledge and application of the policy science framework- Readings- Case studies- Invited guest speakers with extraordinary practical knowledge

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: A syllabus would be nice for understanding and balancing expectations with other commitments, but that's a minor thing. Feedback on the writing assignments is where I would most want to see change. Writing is a much better tool for learning when it is engaged.
Probably better to have two courses a week instead of one long class

Susan's fall course, Foundations of Natural Resource Policy, should be a prerequisite. We spent too much time reviewing the policy sciences - those of us who had taken classes with Susan before wanted a faster pace.

Prerequ for students who have taken a policy sciences course should be seriously considered for this courseConsider placing greater emphasis on readings (esp. Averting Distinction), by spacing them out more, having assignments for, and discussing more in depth these material - and less emph. on presentations and/or papers

Facilitation of discussion, which would be enhanced by having the guest lecturer speak first, or by having students engage in an interactive exercise or small-group discussion and then report findings to the larger group. This was tried twice this semester, with great success.

The class would benefit by more practical applications of the policy sciences. Opening the field trip up to more students would be a start. Also, it would be helpful to have workshops on how to actually conduct workshops related to participatory problem orientation and problem solving.The organization and timing of the class presentations needs attention. The expectation are too high to try to fit 10 or so speakers into one class period. Spreading the presentations over 3 class periods would be helpful.

The course felt a little repetitive in respect to the policy sciences framework. I understand that this framework provides the backbone of the course, but I wished there had been more case studies about various species conservation issues. I loved the black-footed ferret, tasmanian tiger, and ivory-billed woodpecker discussions, I just wanted more of them!

- More examples of successful applications of the policy science framework in the management of species and ecosystems- Full day workshops (out of class) to gather tools to facilitate and explore the social and decision process

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Both were very generous and insightful, bringing their field experience to bear and pointing to additional resources as needed.
Jenn was amazing. Couldn't have a better TA.
Both are outstanding - no room for improvement
Both were very available to answer questions and provide assistance.

Susan and Jenn made their availability to students a top priority, and their time and attention to individual students were invaluable. The concepts taught in this course are very difficult to understand, and Susan and Jenn will work with anyone individually to make sure they get it.
Both Susan and Jenn are always available to students. They both care about students and are always willing to help. They are some of FES' best assets.
See earlier response. Both Susan and Jenn were amazingly involved and helpful in this class, much more committed to the class and the students than in any other FES class I've had.
Susan is one of FES professors who has an open door policy...always available for students for questions and quality advice.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I study human-wildlife conflict, so the course couldn't be more perfect to make me a more successful conservation practitioner.
It is exactly in line with my program.
Perfect fit - conservation biology
Thiscourse synthesizes everything else that I will be learning at Yale and makes it useful in the professional world. It also helps me synthesize my past and current professional experiences.

This is one of the few classes related to wildlife management and conservation. FES is lacking in interdisciplinary classes as well. I am really disappointed that after Steve Kellert leaves, Susan will be the only professor remaining that teaches interdisciplinary classes related to wildlife conservation. FES will be deficient in this area, and should really think about offering more classes and/or hiring more professors.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To learn about the policy process
I took Susan's Large Scale Conservation class last year and loved it, so I knew I should take this one. Plus, my work deals with species and ecosystem conservation, which is the title of the class!
see above
Great professor, love the policy sciences and con bio
Wanted to learn about Susan's unique approach to conservation.
The topic is extremely relevant to my professional interests, and Susan is a great professor.
I am interested in wildlife and social ecologies. This class is a perfect fit.
- gain new professional development skills- learn to further apply the interdisciplinary policy sciences analytical framework learned at Susan's Foundations in Natural Resource Policy course

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Mostly, I definitely learned about the policy process and very helpful ways to approach it.
YES
for the most part. too much review from Susan's fall course.
For the most part
Yes
Yes.
As always, Susan's courses exceed my expectations!

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Almost. I think I was hoping for a magic bullet that would make policy work simpler. I know I would have like more in-depth social systems analysis balancing out the contextual examples.Maybe focus on one endangered species buttressed by reading in Civility and how systems operate instead of more case examples? Would I have then universalized the one example?
YES and more!
for the most part
Generally speaking, yes
Yes
Yes.
Yes..and more!

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Coordinating efforts with others is usually much harder than it was in this group, where everyone was interested in and/or experienced in social process reflection. It was a pleasure, if time-consuming. It was an indispensable part of the class.
Fabulous group, but sometimes difficult to schedule time
Group seemed unnecessary based on the project, but it was interesting to learn more about other peoples' interests.

This was my first real group work at FES, and it was much more difficult than I expected! There was a short deadline, which made coordinating schedules difficult, and I spent so much time with those group-mates in such a short time period that afterwards we were all behind on our other work and didn't see much of each other for the rest of the semester. It's always a good experience to learn more about yourself and others when you work in groups, and it is extremely relevant to real-world experiences.
Advantages: gain experience and patience in a group-settingDisadvantages: bossy second years

The group work was difficult, but a very important part of the course which I valued very much. I was able to understand the policy sciences framework much better when trying to actually apply it to my case study, and working with a group during this process enabled me to learn both from observing them and listening to their feedback about my work.
Learn about commonalities and differences in the management of a diverse number of endangered or threatenedspecies.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Read The Policy Process for this class if you haven't already and don't get hung up on a specific order or picture of the approachunless it helps you. Maybe take Foundations first?
Meet with Susan one-on-one to gain better understanding and to learn more about practical application
Take advantage of the proffs and TAs willingness to talk and mentor

Participate in the field trip if at all possible, and do as many of the readings as you can, because they are one of the most valuable parts of the course, when combined with the instruction from Susan that helps to clarify them and put them in perspective.
This is a great class. You do well just by being engaged and trying your best. Start your paper and presentations early!

If you are interested in Species and Ecosystem Management, this is the course for you. It is an eye-opener!Susan is THE expert on this subject at FES and no one is better qualified to teach the importance of the policy sciences framework and its application towards species and ecosystems management.
